questions.prompt: 1. In BG 17.1-3, what are the three types of faith?
questions.feedback: Faith manifests according to the three modes of material nature.

questions.prompt: 2. In BG 17.2, what characterizes those with sattvic faith?
choices: Steady faith in God, devotion to the Absolute Truth, and belief in karma-yoga
questions.feedback: Sattvic faith is rooted in spiritual understanding and truth.

questions.prompt: 3. In BG 17.4, what characterizes those with rajasic faith?
choices: Selfish desires for results; faith motivated by personal gain and enjoyment
questions.feedback: Rajasic faith is conditional and motivated by personal benefit.

questions.prompt: 4. In BG 17.4, what is the nature of tamasic faith?
choices: Ignorant, confused, and rooted in superstition; following blind faith without understanding
questions.feedback: Tamasic faith is based on darkness and lacks rational understanding.

questions.prompt: 5. In BG 17.4-5, what are sattvic, rajasic, and tamasic foods?
choices: Sattvic: pure, nutritious, life-enhancing | Rajasic: spicy, overstimulating | Tamasic: spoiled, dull
questions.feedback: Food influences consciousness according to the modes of nature.

questions.prompt: 6. In BG 17.11-12, what are the three types of charity?
choices: Sattvic (given from duty, to worthy persons); rajasic (with expectation); tamasic (improper giving)
questions.feedback: Charity reflects the donor's consciousness and the three modes.

questions.prompt: 7. In BG 17.11, what defines sattvic charity?
choices: Given at the proper time and place to a worthy recipient without expectation of return
questions.feedback: Sattvic charity is pure, selfless, and rightly directed.

questions.prompt: 8. In BG 17.12, what defines rajasic charity?
choices: Given with expectation of return or for recognition
questions.feedback: Rajasic charity is motivated by desire for benefit and reputation.

questions.prompt: 9. In BG 17.13, what defines tamasic charity?
choices: Given at the wrong place and time to an unworthy recipient with disrespect
questions.feedback: Tamasic charity creates no benefit and may cause harm.

questions.prompt: 10. In BG 17.14-16, what are the three types of austerity?
choices: Sattvic: bodily/mental/vocal discipline | Rajasic: performed for results | Tamasic: self-torturing
questions.feedback: Austerity also has three modes based on the modes of nature.

questions.prompt: 11. In BG 17.14-15, what defines sattvic austerity?
choices: Discipline of mind, speech, and body; control without discomfort
questions.feedback: Sattvic austerity brings clarity and spiritual advancement.

questions.prompt: 12. In BG 17.15, what defines rajasic austerity?
choices: Performed for gain, recognition, or to impress others; unstable
questions.feedback: Rajasic austerity is conditional and seeks external rewards.

questions.prompt: 13. In BG 17.16, what defines tamasic austerity?
choices: Self-torture without purpose; done in ignorance and causing harm
questions.feedback: Tamasic austerity is harmful and based on delusion.

questions.prompt: 14. In BG 17.20-21, what is sattvic renunciation?
choices: The performance of duty without attachment to results, steadily and with focus
questions.feedback: True renunciation is detached action, not the rejection of action.

questions.prompt: 15. In BG 17.21, what is rajasic renunciation?
choices: Abandoning duties out of fear or dislike, but with attachment to results
questions.feedback: Rajasic renunciation is incomplete and motivated by ego.

questions.prompt: 16. In BG 17.22, what is tamasic renunciation?
choices: Complete abandonment of all duty and responsibility out of laziness and delusion
questions.feedback: Tamasic renunciation is mere escapism and causes confusion.

questions.prompt: 17. In BG 17.3 (from purport), what determines the type of faith a person has?
choices: One's nature or consciousness according to the three modes of material nature
questions.feedback: Faith reflects one's inner consciousness and spiritual development.

questions.prompt: 18. In BG 17.5-7 (from purport), why does Krishna discuss food in terms of the modes?
choices: Food affects consciousness and spiritual development; what we eat shapes what we become
questions.feedback: Food is a spiritual matter affecting consciousness and progress.

questions.prompt: 19. In BG 17.11-13 (from purport), what is the significance of sattvic charity over others?
choices: It purifies the giver and benefits the receiver genuinely without creating false expectations
questions.feedback: Sattvic charity is the highest form and brings real benefit.

questions.prompt: 20. In BG 17.14-16 (from purport), how does austerity connect to spiritual progress?
choices: Sattvic austerity purifies consciousness and develops spiritual wisdom
questions.feedback: True austerity is a tool for spiritual transformation.

questions.prompt: 21. In BG 17.20-22 (from purport), what is the ultimate renunciation Krishna teaches?
choices: Acting according to duty without attachment to results; karma-yoga
questions.feedback: Krishna's renunciation is internal (non-attachment), not external (abandonment of duty).

questions.prompt: 22. In BG 17 (summary), what is the central teaching?
choices: The three modes of nature determine all our actions; spiritual progress comes through sattvic choices
questions.feedback: Chapter 17 teaches conscious evolution through the modes of nature.

questions.prompt: 23. In BG 17.4-5 (from purport), what is an example of sattvic food?
choices: Milk products, fruits, vegetables, and grains; pure, natural foods
questions.feedback: Sattvic foods are pure and promote spiritual awareness.

questions.prompt: 24. In BG 17.2-4 (from purport), what is the progression suggested for spiritual growth?
choices: Moving from tamasic to rajasic to sattvic faith and consciousness
questions.feedback: Spiritual development is a progression through the modes.

questions.prompt: 25. In BG 17.27 (from purport), what does 'OM TAT SAT' represent?
choices: The Absolute Truth; sattvic action performed for God, without ego
questions.feedback: OM TAT SAT represents transcendental action and dedication to the Absolute.
